awd_titl_txt: Using a Culturally Responsive Teaching Framework to Prepare Middle and High School Mathematics Teachers
awd_abstract_narration:
With funding from the National Science Foundation's Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship program, the University of North Carolina at Charlotte's Culturally Responsive Teaching (UNCC CResT) project will recruit undergraduate majors in mathematics and prepare them to become middle and high school mathematics teachers. The project will fund 24 scholarships over 5 years. In this project, UNC Charlotte will collaborate with Charlotte-Mecklenburg School District to develop and prepare scholars with the knowledge, skills, and dispositions necessary to engage culturally and linguistically diverse students in mathematics classrooms.  

The Culturally Responsive Teaching (CRT) framework will guide the development of the Noyce scholars by building on the knowledge and experiences of culturally and linguistically diverse (CLD) students. This framework views the culture and experiences of diverse students as resources, rather than deficits that can be used to build higher interest in content. The CRT framework will better prepare the Noyce scholars to work with CLD students who form the majority of students in high-needs school in the Charlotte area and many urban and rural districts across North Carolina. In addition to completing content and pedagogy courses, the scholars will (i) learn about CLD students through professional interactions and reflecting on these experiences, (ii) develop and advance their understandings of CRT practices through seminars about CRT and teaching CLD students, and (iii) draw on personal experiences to develop and teach mathematics lessons that build on the cultural and lived experiences of CLD students.

por.por_cntn:
This project was a collaborative effort between the University of North Carolina at Charlotte and Charlotte-Mecklenburg Schools, aimed at addressing the urgent need for qualified middle and high school mathematics teachers in North Carolina. A primary goal of the initiative was to develop culturally responsive mathematics educators capable of meeting the needs of underrepresented students. In addition to completing coursework, scholars participated in seminars focused on Culturally Responsive Teaching and lesson design. Scholars also gained hands-on experience in their mentor teachers' classrooms, working closely with 2-3 students throughout the year. This allowed scholars to deepen their understanding of the students’ out-of-school experiences while offering targeted support in mathematics. The scholars also engaged in various teacher-related activities, including leading mini-lessons, attending parent-teacher conferences, participating in planning meetings with mathematics faculty, and contributing to Individualized Education Plan meetings. This immersive experience was essential to shaping future educators who are both theoretically and practically equipped to teach in diverse and high-need school settings. It is important to acknowledge that the COVID-19 pandemic disrupted all in-person activities for both the university and schools. Scholars were unable to complete their face-to-face interactions with students in school settings. In response, the project adapted by pivoting to an online format, where scholars engaged in critical readings of two influential books: Reading and Writing the World with Mathematics and How to Be an Antiracist. These readings had a profound impact on their perspectives and professional development.

Originally, the project aimed to prepare three cohorts of eight teachers each. However, it exceeded expectations by supporting a total of 36 scholars, 29 of whom graduated to teach in high-needs school districts. These scholars were mentored by 50 experienced teachers from four neighboring school districts, all of whom received support from the project. Additionally, 23 STEM majors were provided with summer and semester internships in various educational settings, including programs for underrepresented youth, robotics club, and assisting teachers in school. These internships sought to foster an interest in teaching and encourage the participants to think of becoming mathematics teachers.

The project resulted in significant scholarly output, including 15 conference presentations and posters, and two journal articles. One article examined the modification of an existing culturally responsive teaching scale based on the scholars’ design of culturally responsive mathematics lessons. The second article built upon a data investigation activity introduced during the seminars. The project was also part of a longitudinal Track 4 Noyce study (NSF # 1758401), which explored the equitable teaching practices of early-career teachers who were scholars in this project. Further, funding was secured through NSF IUSE (NSF #2121364) to develop two of the activities from the seminars into modules that are shared with mathematics teacher educators to be used in their mathematics content courses for future teachers. Despite the challenges posed by the pandemic, the project succeeded in achieving its goals and made a significant contribution to the preparation of culturally responsive mathematics teachers.
